Indications and doses

Thyrotoxic crisis (thyroid storm),

By intravenous injection

  • For adults
    100 mg every 6 hours, to be administered as sodium succinate.

Adrenocortical insufficiency resulting from septic shock,

By intravenous injection

  • For adults
    50 mg every 6 hours, given in combination with fludrocortisone.

Acute hypersensitivity reactions such as angioedema of the upper respiratory tract and anaphylaxis (adjunct to adrenaline),

By intravenous injection

  • For adults
    100–300 mg, to be administered as sodium succinate.

Corticosteroid replacement, in patients who have taken more than 10 mg prednisolone daily (or equivalent) within 3 months of minor surgery under general anaesthesia,

By intravenous injection or by intravenous infusion

  • For adults
    Initially 25–50 mg, to be administered at induction of surgery, the patient's usual oral corticosteroid dose is recommenced after surgery.

Corticosteroid replacement, in patients who have taken more than 10 mg prednisolone daily (or equivalent) within 3 months of moderate or major surgery,

By intravenous injection or by intravenous infusion

  • For adults
    Initially 25–50 mg, to be administered at induction of surgery (following usual oral corticosteroid dose on the morning of surgery), followed by 25–50 mg 3 times a day for 24 hours after moderate surgery and for 48–72 hours after major surgery.

Adrenocortical insufficiency in Addison’s disease or following adrenalectomy,

By mouth using immediate-release medicines

  • For adults
    20–30 mg daily in 2 divided doses, the larger dose to be given in the morning and the smaller in the evening, mimicking the normal diurnal rhythm of cortisol secretion, the optimum daily dose is determined on the basis of clinical response.

Adrenocortical insufficiency,

By intramuscular injection or by slow intravenous injection or by intravenous infusion

  • For adults
    100–500 mg 3–4 times a day or when required.

Severe inflammatory bowel disease,

By slow intravenous injection or by intravenous infusion

  • For adults
    100–500 mg 3–4 times a day or when required.

Replacement in adrenocortical insufficiency,

By mouth using immediate-release medicines

  • For adults
    20–30 mg once daily, adjusted according to response, dose to be taken in the morning.
  • For adults
    20–30 mg daily in divided doses, adjusted according to response.

Ulcerative colitis, Proctitis, Proctosigmoiditis,

By rectum using rectal foam

  • For adults
    Initially 1 metered application 1–2 times a day for 2–3 weeks, then reduced to 1 metered application once daily on alternate days, to be inserted into the rectum.

Acute hypersensitivity reactions, Angioedema,

By intramuscular injection or by intravenous injection

  • For children 1–5 months
    Initially 25 mg 3 times a day, adjusted according to response.
  • For children 6 months–5 years
    Initially 50 mg 3 times a day, adjusted according to response.
  • For children 6–11 years
    Initially 100 mg 3 times a day, adjusted according to response.
  • For children 12–17 years
    Initially 200 mg 3 times a day, adjusted according to response.

Mild inflammatory skin disorders such as eczemas,

To the skin

  • For adults
    Apply 1–2 times a day, to be applied thinly.
  • For children
    Apply 1–2 times a day, to be applied thinly.

Nappy rash,

To the skin

  • For children
    Apply as required for no more than 1 week, discontinued as soon as the inflammation subsides.

Severe acute asthma, Life-threatening acute asthma,

By intravenous injection

  • For adults
    100 mg every 6 hours until conversion to oral prednisolone is possible, dose given, preferably, as sodium succinate.
  • For children 1 month–1 year
    4 mg/kg every 6 hours (max. per dose 100 mg), alternatively 25 mg every 6 hours until conversion to oral prednisolone is possible, dose given, preferably, as sodium succinate.
  • For children 2–4 years
    4 mg/kg every 6 hours (max. per dose 100 mg), alternatively 50 mg every 6 hours until conversion to oral prednisolone is possible, dose given, preferably, as sodium succinate.
  • For children 5–11 years
    4 mg/kg every 6 hours (max. per dose 100 mg), alternatively 100 mg every 6 hours until conversion to oral prednisolone is possible, dose given, preferably, as sodium succinate.

Oral and perioral lesions,

By buccal administration

  • For adults
    1 lozenge 4 times a day, allowed to dissolve slowly in the mouth in contact with the ulcer.
  • For children 1 month–11 years
    Only on medical advice.
  • For children 12–17 years
    1 lozenge 4 times a day, allowed to dissolve slowly in the mouth in contact with the ulcer.

Dose equivalence and conversion

When switching from immediate-release hydrocortisone tablets to modified release Plenadren use same total daily dose. Bioavailability of Plenadren lower than immediate release tablets—monitor clinical response.

Potency of preperations

Hydrocortisone cream and ointment 0.5 to 2.5%: mild

Contra indications

Known side effects

Specific side effects

notKnown: local sensitivity reactions, phosphate ester associated with pain and paraesthesia (particularly in the perineal region), candidal infection, exacerbation of local infection, local irritation,

Directions for administration

With intravenous use in children

For intravenous administration, dilute with Glucose 5% or Sodium Chloride 0.9%.

For intermittent infusion give over 20–30 minutes.

With oral use in children

For administration by mouth, injection solution may be swallowed [unlicensed use] but consider phosphate content.

Alternatively Corlan pellets may be swallowed [unlicensed use]—pellets should not be cut as may not provide appropriate dose.

With intravenous use in adults

For intravenous infusion (as sodium succinate) (SoluCortef ), give continuously or intermittently or via drip tubing in Glucose 5% or Sodium chloride 0.9%.

Advice for patients and carers

With systemic use

Patient counselling is advised for hydrocortisone tablets and injections (steroid card).

With topical use

Patient counselling is advised for hydrocortisone cream and ointment (application).

Cautions regarding administration

  • When used by ear: avoid prolonged use
  • With rectal use: systemic absorption may occur

Unlicensed use

With buccal use in children

Hydrocortisone mucoadhesive buccal tablets licensed for use in children (under 12 years—on medical advice only).

Use of injection by mouth is unlicensed.

Systemic use of Corlan pellets is unlicensed.

Information regarding prescribing and dispensing

With topical use

When hydrocortisone cream or ointment is prescribed and no strength is stated, the 1% strength should be supplied.

Conditions when less suitable for prescribing

Hydrocortisone as the sodium phosphate is less suitable for prescribing as paraesthesia and pain (particularly in the perineal region) may follow intravenous injection.

Profession specific information

Dental practitioners

With buccal use

Mucoadhesive buccal tablets may be prescribed as Hydrocortisone Oromucosal Tablets.

With topical use

Hydrocortisone Cream 1% 15 g may be prescribed.

Exceptions to legal category

With intramuscular use or intravenous use

Prescription only medicine restriction does not apply where administration is for saving life in emergency.

With topical use

Over-the-counter hydrocortisone preparations

Skin creams and ointments containing hydrocortisone (alone or with other ingredients) can be sold to the public for the treatment of allergic contact dermatitis, irritant dermatitis, insect bite reactions and mild to moderate eczema in patients over 10 years, to be applied sparingly over the affected area 1–2 times daily for max. 1 week. Over-the-counter hydrocortisone preparations should not be sold without medical advice for children under 10 years or for pregnant women; they should not be sold for application to the face, anogenital region, broken or infected skin (including cold sores, acne, and athlete’s foot).

Prepared medicinal forms of HYDROCORTISONE

There can be variation in the licensing of different medicines containing the same drug.

Forms available from special-order manufacturers include: suppository, oral suspension, oral solution, capsule, eye ointment, liquid, pastille,
